awd_titl_txt: Sequential Detection and Prediction for Solar Situation Awareness in Power Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching research objective of this project is to develop statistical tools to help power network operators in increasing the solar generator situational awareness. The goals include inferring the solar power generators, their locations, and status, from the real-time power supply and consumption data using sequential data. We take a novel approach leveraging the fact that the on and off of the solar generators will introduce change-points in the difference time series of the power supply and consumption, and propose a statistical framework for solar situational awareness by detecting change-points and estimating their magnitudes from sequential data. We use a bottom-up approach, which is a natural fit to the hierarchical structure of the power networks: we detect change-points at the unit level, and then aggregate them on a network level, using multi-dimensional point process model, as well as considering the inherent sparse and low-dimensional nature of the observations. The change-point detection will be combined with multi-fidelity models to achieve network level prediction of power generation. The results will be verified on simulated high-fidelity time-series and real-data over dynamic power networks.

Solar power installations have been increasing in both the residential and commercial areas. However, it is very difficult to know the exact numbers, locations, installed capacities, and production status of these PV panels, especially due to the increasing number of behind-the-meter installations of PV panels and the intrinsic stochasticity in solar production. Not knowing the status of the solar generators in the network can pose a significant challenge to stability and security of power distribution and transmission systems. The precise knowledge of the number, location, capacity, and operational status of residential PV units within a distribution system will be very critical to the daily operation and planning of distribution system and eventually that of transmission systems. Currently, there is no effective way to infer in real-time the solar generators' status in a large-scale power network. The proposed research will change the landscape and significantly advance the state-of-the-art in using statistical methods for solar situational awareness. Utility companies, industry regulators and solar panel marketers are a few of the groups that will benefit from the algorithm developed for situational awareness. For example, having access to detailed information of the status of solar PV production in a given neighborhood can enable local utilities to better balance the area's power supply and demand, improve the quality of electricity service to end users, and increase the reliability and security of distribution power grids. The proposed research will be tightly integrated with education components, and the research results will be made available to national labs as open source software and research findings will be disseminated via conferences and journal publications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project, conducted in collaboration with Argonne National Laboratory, aims to develop innovative spatio-temporal predictive models to address pressing challenges in power grids and networks, particularly under the uncertainty introduced by weather variability and the increasing penetration of renewable energy sources. These challenges include the significant fluctuations in solar and wind power output due to weather conditions, extreme weather events, and hazardous situations such as wildfires. With renewable energy integration growing rapidly, the uncertainties in power generation and grid stability have become critical issues for energy systems worldwide. Our research addresses these problems through a series of interconnected studies, including the prediction of solar power ramping events, wind power generation with uncertainty quantification, wildfire impacts on power grids, and the analysis of large-scale power outages to enhance resilience and operational reliability. For example, predicting solar ramping events—sudden and significant deviations in solar energy generation from expected levels—is crucial for maintaining system stability and situational awareness. These events are strongly influenced by factors such as temperature, humidity, and cloud density. To address this challenge, we developed a novel spatio-temporal interactive Bernoulli process framework that surpasses traditional Hawkes process models. This framework captures not only binary events but also categorical event data, allowing for more detailed analysis of increases, decreases, and changes in magnitude in solar output. Furthermore, the method is computationally efficient, leveraging convex optimization techniques for scalable inference. Our approach has demonstrated excellent performance on real-world solar radiation datasets, enabling a better understanding of spatial and temporal correlations in complex and noisy systems.

In addition to solar energy forecasting, we proposed a multi-resolution Gaussian process method to predict spatio-temporal wind power generation with uncertainty quantification. This approach allows for more accurate and reliable forecasts by accounting for the inherent variability in wind energy resources, thereby providing actionable insights for grid operators. Another major focus of the project has been on modeling and predicting the impact of wildfires on power grids. Wildfires pose severe risks to energy infrastructure, and our work incorporates a distribution-free uncertainty quantification framework using conformal prediction techniques to improve hazard prediction and mitigation strategies. Furthermore, we developed change-point detection algorithms tailored for power grids to identify failures quickly, particularly cascading failures that can lead to widespread outages. These algorithms enhance the ability of power operators to respond to disruptions in real-time, reducing system downtime and associated costs. Analyzing large-scale outage data has also been a significant part of this project. By integrating comprehensive weather variables as contextual information into spatio-temporal models, we have gained new insights into the resilience of power systems to extreme weather and events. Moreover, we introduced a statistical counterfactual fairness framework to study energy justice, ensuring equitable power distribution during adverse conditions, particularly in vulnerable communities.

The impact of this project goes beyond research advancements, fostering substantial educational and professional development opportunities for students and researchers. Through this initiative, several Ph.D. students were supported, contributing to research papers that became integral components of their dissertations and all of them have graduated (becoming data scientists and researchers in industry and one becoming an Assistant Professor at a top university). Additionally, our collaboration with Argonne National Laboratory provided students with invaluable internship opportunities. These internships allowed participants to engage deeply with real-world challenges, translating complex problems into statistical models and solving them using advanced mathematical tools. The internships also resulted in several papers, which were subsequently submitted to conferences and journals. Beyond graduate education, the project has also impacted undergraduate students. For instance, a Georgia Tech undergraduate involved in the research was recognized with the Presidential Undergraduate Research Award (PURA) at Georgia Tech. The integration of research outcomes into Georgia Tech's curriculum has further enriched the educational experience for students. Examples derived from this research are now part of both graduate and undergraduate courses, offering students practical, real-world applications of theoretical concepts.

The project results have been widely disseminated: Findings have been shared through various platforms, including preprints on arXiv, publications in leading peer-reviewed conferences and journals, and presentations at professional forums such as INFORMS and NSF workshops. These efforts have facilitated knowledge exchange and highlighted the broader significance of our work in the fields of signal processing, statistics, and energy systems. Moreover, we have made open-source implementations of our methods available on GitHub. The collaboration with Argonne National Laboratory has been instrumental in translating our findings into practical applications. By integrating our methods and results into Argonne’s platforms, we have demonstrated the real-world utility of our research, further validating its relevance and impact. Overall, this project has advanced the development of spatio-temporal predictive models for power systems, contributing to improved situational awareness, operational efficiency, and resilience in energy management. Beyond the immediate scope of power systems, the methodologies developed through this work are broadly applicable to other applications.
